intro: Psilactis coulteri, commonly known as Coulter's psilactis, is a rare flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white to greenish-yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland habitats. Due to habitat loss, it is considered endangered and is protected in several states.
